0848577 |blank1_name = |blank1_info = |website = [http://www.cityoflovelock.com City of Lovelock] |footnotes = }} '''Lovelock''' is the county seat of [[Pershing County, Nevada|Pershing County]], [[Nevada]], in which it is the only incorporated city. It is the namesake of a nearby [[Lovelock Correctional Center|medium-security men's prison]] and a [[Cold War]]-era [[Black Rock Desert Gunnery Range|gunnery range]]. Formerly a stop for [[California Gold Rush|settlers on their way to California]] and later a train depot, the town's economy is now based primarily on tourism and employment at the prison. ==Geography== Lovelock lies in the [[Humboldt River]] Basin, very near the terminus of the river. Some twenty miles outside the town is the [[Lovelock Cave|Lovelock Native Cave]], a horseshoe-shaped cave of about {{convert|35|ft|m|abbr=on|adj=mid|width}} and {{convert|150|ft|m|abbr=on|adj=mid|length}} where Northern [[Paiute]] natives anciently deposited a number of duck decoys and other artifacts.[http://www.nevadabeautiful.com/pony-express/lovelock-caves-lovelock-nevada.html "Lovelock Caves, Lovelock Nevada"] NevadaBeautiful.com, Retrieved 14 February 2010. According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|0.9|sqmi|km2}}, all of it land. It has four differently designed welcome signs with pioneer and [[Wild West]] themes placed on its approach roads. ==Demographics== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 2,003 people, 778 households, and 493 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2,311.6 people per square mile (888.9/km²). There were 951 housing units at an average density of 1,097.5 per square mile (422.0/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 76.49% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.80% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 7.14% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.70% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.20% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 10.03% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4.64% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 24.21% of the population. There were 778 households out of which 33.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 47.8% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 9.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 36.6% were non-families. 31.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 12.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.52 and the average family size was 3.22. In the city the population was spread out with 31.2% under the age of 18, 7.5% from 18 to 24, 27.2% from 25 to 44, 20.9% from 45 to 64, and 13.3% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females there were 107.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.2 males. The median income for a household in the city was $34,563, and the median income for a family was $40,885. Males had a median income of $35,658 versus $27,371 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $17,233. About 9.6% of families and 14.2% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 18.9% of those under age 18 and 10.3% of those age 65 or over. The majority rely on agriculture and mining for their income. ==History== The area in which the township of Lovelock was to be established first came to prominence as a lush way station on the Humboldt Trail to California. According to an 1849 description of what were then called the Big Meadows, "This marsh for three miles is certainly the liveliest place that one could witness in a lifetime. There is some two hundred and fifty wagons here all the time. Trains going out and others coming in and taking their places is the constant order of the day. Cattle and mules by the hundreds are surrounding us, in grass to their knees, all discoursing sweet music with the grinding of their jaws.”Quoted in David W. Toll, ''A brief Description & History of Lovelock, Nevada'', [http://www.nevadaweb.com/cnt/cc/lovelock.html available online] [[File:The Humboldt River near Lovelock.JPG|left|260px|thumb|The Humboldt River near Lovelock]] A few settlers stopped on there to harvest the wild rye growing in the meadows and scythe the hay each fall, which they then sold on. Arriving there from California in 1866, the English settler George Lovelock (1824–1907) bought the squatters' right for 320 acres and got with it the oldest water rights on the Humboldt River. Although born in [[Wales]], Lovelock was from a family of [[Wiltshire]] origin that is known to family historians as the Lyneham Line.Sue Lovelock, ''From Wiltshire to Nevada – tracing the Lovelock connection'', Lovelock Lines 4, January 2006 [http://lovelock.free.fr/l-lines/lovelock-lines-4th-ed.pdf pp.3-5] His brother Daniel moved to [[Australia]] - and one of Daniel's sons to [[New Zealand]] - so that the relations of the man after whom the Nevada town was named are now widely scattered. The town's foundation came about with the building of the [[Southern Pacific Railroad]] through the area in August 1868. George Lovelock provided 85 acres for the site and the depot was therefore named 'Lovelock's' after him and appears as such on old maps.An early example is on Mitchell's [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d0/1872_Mitchell_Map_of_Utah_and_Nevada_-_Geographicus_-_UTNV-mitchell-1872.jpg map of Nevada] (1872) Thereafter he put his mining expertise to work and discovered many valuable lodes in the surrounding area, which contributed to enhanced railway traffic. He also acted as the town's first postmaster and invested in hotels. In particular he was the first proprietor of the Big Meadows Hotel on Main Street, adjacent to the train station and what was eventually the [[Greyhound Lines|Greyhound Bus]] depot. By 1900, the town of Lovelock had a school, churches and a business district along what was then called Railway Street - later renamed West Broadway.Thomas Wren, ''A History of the State of Nevada: Its Resources and People'', Lewis Publishing Company 1904 [http://www.ksgennet.org/nv/pr/bios/lovelockgeorge.html available online] Also included among the businesses were no less than three weekly newspapers: The ''Lovelock Tribune'', which ran from May 1898 until February 1912; the short-lived ''Lovelock Standard'' (April–September 1900); and ''The Argus'' (May 1900-Jan 1905). In August 1908 the weekly ''Lovelock Review'' was founded, becoming ''Lovelock Review-Miner'' in January 1911 and remaining under that name to the present day.Richard E. Lingenfelter, Karen Rix Gash, ''The newspapers of Nevada: a history and bibliography, 1854-1979'', University of Nevada 1984 [http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PQqhz7JSQZUC&pg=PA146&lpg=PA146&dq=lovelock+review+miner+newspaper&source=bl&ots=MbOFfGdKAA&sig=sXI4C0yllVg373XBgcK7eR_L4Pw&hl=en&ei=PgWvTr3CHI-m8gPcsdixCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&sqi=2&ved=0CF0Q6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=lovelock%20&f=false pp.144-7] [[File:Lovelock77.jpg|right|thumb|285px|Downtown Main Street and Cornell Avenue]] Lovelock was incorporated as a city in 1917 and in 1919 it was named the county seat when Pershing County was carved out of the southern part of Humboldt County. Its famous round Court House was built at the end of Main Street, on the site of a school, which was then located elsewhere. While mining and agriculture acted as the commercial centre for the locality, the community thrived on the state speciality of gambling, with many casinos and [[List of brothels in Nevada|three legalised brothels]], although all of the latter are now closed. The town’s centenary was celebrated in 1968 with a Frontier Days theme suggested by two of the founder’s great-great granddaughters, Elaine Pommerening and Pat Rowe, who had only recently moved back to Lovelock. In 1983, [[Nevada State Route 396|old U.S. Route 40]] through downtown was bypassed by [[Interstate 80 in Nevada|Interstate 80]], and in the early 1990s the rail depot closed, killing much of its prosperity. Since then it has promoted itself as a tourist attraction with its historic buildings and special events. There have been several mining booms in the neighbouring mountains. These included intensive activity in the [[Rochester, Nevada|Rochester]] and [[Seven Troughs Range|Seven Troughs]] areas at the start of the 20th century and subsequent drilling with more advanced techniques later in Rochester. The Coeur Rochester mine began further open cast mining for silver and gold in 2011,[http://www.coeur.com/operations/rochester-nevada#.UkQ_Nn-57ec Coeur.com] test drilling for gold continues at Relief Canyon,[http://www.pershinggold.com/projects/relief-canyon-mine-project-nevada Pershing Gold Co.] and diatomite is dug at the Colado Mine.[http://mines.findthedata.org/l/40370/Colado-Mine Mine data online] ==Tourism== Among the tourist events figure the I.D.E.S. Portuguese festival in May and what became the annual Frontier Days weekend in July. There are also hot air balloon races (Lovers Aloft, inaugurated in February 2004) and the Lovelock Street Fever car show, begun in June 2007. A major draw is the Lovers Lock Plaza in the shaded area at the back of the Court House where couples symbolise their love by attaching a padlock to an 'endless chain', a practice begun on Valentine’s Day, 2005.{{cite web |url=http://loverslock.com/ |title=The perfect romantic gift idea. "Locking your love" in Lovelock, Nevada. |publisher=Lovelock/Pershing County Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=2010-05-17}} The following year saw the construction of a dirt-racing track known as the Lovelock Speedway.{{dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Nevada/Localities/L/Lovelock}} Lovelock's heritage buildings include the wooden built Grace Methodist Church on the corner of Cornell Avenue and 8th Street, dating from 1886. It was destroyed by fire in 1922 and the tower was rebuilt without the original spire; in 1983 the church was badly damaged by another fire and was restored again. [[Marzen House]] Museum is another Victorian building, built in 1874. The Italianate farmhouse was transported from Big Meadow Ranch in the 1980s and has on its site an assay office, farm machinery sheds, and buildings housing vintage automobiles, while inside it contains 1800s furnishings and a museum, shedding light on the area’s history.[http://museums.travelnevada.com/destination/marzen-house-museum.aspx Online information] [[File:Pershingcourt.JPG|thumb|left|285px|Pershing County Court House in Lovelock]] Among so much that that has been otherwise torn down and not replaced in the town, the Longhorn Bar beside the tracks on West Broadway is one of the few remaining commercial buildings in typical Nevada style. Not far away is the [[Central Pacific Railroad Depot (Lovelock, Nevada)|railroad depot]] dating from 1880. In 1999 it was presented to the town by the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] to be restored and moved to another lot for use as an eatery. This was registered as a historic building in 2004.[http://pdfhost.focus.nps.gov/docs/NRHP/Text/04000300.pdf Registration online] Pride of place goes to the distinctive [[Pershing County Courthouse]], dating from 1919. Julie Nicoletta describes the circimstances: 'Pershing County officials approached [[Frederic Joseph DeLongchamps]], by then the architect of six Nevada courthouses, and asked for a design that would be low in price but distinctive in appearance. As a solution, DeLongchamps designed a round courthouse, patterning it after [[Thomas Jefferson Library|Thomas Jefferson's library]] at the [[University of Virginia]] campus. The circle-over-hexagon design includes a circular interior hallway and a round courtroom decorated with [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] [[pilasters]]. A broad, sweeping concrete staircase leads to the main floor of the [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts classical structure]]. Its entrance includes a pedimented portico supported by six [[Ionic order|Ionic]] columns. [[Doric order|Doric]] pilasters separate the main story windows. Cream-colored brick and [[terracotta]] finish the exterior. A shallow dome crowns the roof and provides the courtroom with a dramatic, soaring ceiling.'Julie Nicoletta, ''Buildings of Nevada'', Oxford University Press USA, 2000, ISBN 0-19-514139-3 A tourist attraction of a completely different kind, the [[Lovelock Correctional Center]] was opened in 1995 and is best known for the fact that in 2008 [[O.J. Simpson]] began a prison sentence there.[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/dec/19/oj-tranferred-lovelock/ "O.J. transferred to Lovelock"] LasVegasSun.com, 19 December 2008, Retrieved 29 July 2009. ==Lovelock in song and story== There is something about the resonance of the town's name that has appealed to song writers. It is referenced on the debut album of the folk-rock band Center Divide, ''Lovelock to Winnemucca'' (1998), a title drawn from the opening lines of the first song there, "Lovelock".[http://www.centerdivide.com/lovelock.htm Lyrics] The sad lyrics contemplate lost love as the car speeds down the bleak highway between the Nevada towns. [[File:CowpokeCafeLovelock.jpg||thumb|250px|The Cowpoke Cafe in Lovelock]] The wry “Limbo in Lovelock”, first performed in 2005 by the [[Hot Buttered Rum (band)|Hot Buttered Rum]] String Band,There is a performance on the [http://www.archive.org/details/HBRSB2005-06-24.flac16 Internet Live Music Archive] was eventually recorded on their ''Live in the Northeast'' CD (2007). Although at first a stopover in the town is made to sound like a doorway to hell, the mood changes at the end. :::Well just outside of nowhere, mile marker 105, :::You'll find yourself in Lovelock where the game’s to stay alive; :::Get yourself a burger down at the Cowpoke Café, :::Where the gals have quite a smile, it's the special of the day.[http://www.morebutter.net/missyslist/song_details.php?id=29 The full lyrics] Interviewed about the meaning of this verse, one of the band reminisced that they had stopped at the diner and noticed a sign on the counter 'explaining the special of the day. The girls working there were teenagers and full of smiles and good cheer. It was very welcome after a trying day on the road. I'd say the girls' smiles were the special of the day because they really cheered us up.'''Butter Times" 6 (Fall 2005) [http://www.hotbutteredrum.net/pdf/BT6.pdf p.3] “Lovelock” is also the second track on Pitch Black‘s second album, ''This is the Modern Sound'' (Revelation Records, 2005).[http://www.myspace.com/pitchblacknz/music/albums/this-is-the-modern-sound-11015484 Listen online] Though the words are difficult to make out, a review informs us that this is a typically punk ‘us against the world anthem’.[http://blogcritics.org/music/article/review-pitch-black-this-is-the Read online] Other songs referencing mining towns and imagery explain why the name "Lovelock" was chosen. A stopover in the town is the subject of Fred Leebron's prize-winning short story “Lovelock”, originally published in ''[[Ploughshares]]'' magazine in 1993. An ex-convict staying overnight at a Lovelock motel picks up a retarded woman and guiltily sees her and her sister off in their car the next morning. Leebron explains that the inspiration for the story 'comes from a brief encounter I had in New Orleans in 1985 and an overnight stay I made in Nevada four years later. I began writing a novel that contains "Lovelock" as a chapter in the spring of 1992.'[http://www.pshares.org/read/article-detail.cfm?intArticleID=3716 Magazine website] The story was reprinted in the anthology ''Voices of the Exiled'' (Doubleday 1994); the novel into which it was incorporated, ''Out West'', appeared in 1996. [[Stephen Bly]]’s Wild West novel ''Dangerous Ride Across Humboldt Flats'' (Crossway Press, 2003) deals with the area before the town was built. In the opening chapters, an orphaned [[Pony Express]] rider comes across Trent Lovelock and his family on Humboldt Flats in 1860 and is befriended by them.The first two chapters are currently available [http://www.gnpcb.org/assets/products/excerpts/1581344724.1.pdf online] Although George Lovelock had yet to set out for Nevada at that time, the author has acknowledged that he had the town's founder in mind in his fictitious Trent Lovelock.Yann Lovelock, “Lovelock Avatars”, ''Lovelock Lines'' 6, December 2007 [http://lovelock.free.fr/l-lines/lovelock-lines-6th-ed.pdf p.7] Finally, Lovelock has a poet of its own in [[Adrian C. Louis]], who was brought up on the small reservation for [[Lovelock Paiute Tribe of the Lovelock Indian Colony|Lovelock Paiute Indians]] south of the town. The presence of the Indian Cemetery there is an abiding point of reference for him and a place to which he often returns, in person and more often, in memory. :::I'm at that place I grew up to leave. :::Alkali-crusted sand waves have drifted against my markers of blood."Indian Cemetery: Lovelock, Nevada", ''Fire Water World'', Albuquerque NM, 1989 (ISBN 0931122511 / 0-931122-51-1) ==People associated to Lovelock== *[[Robert Heizer]], archaeologist *[[Wayde Preston]], actor *[[Edna Purviance]], actress * [[O._J._Simpson|O.J. Simpson]], American football player ==See also== *[[The Buena Vista Iron Ore District]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nevadaweb.com/cnt/cc/lovelock.html http://www.nevadaweb.com/cnt/cc/lovelock.html] * [http://www.loverslock.com/About-Lovelock-Nevada.html http://www.loverslock.com/About-Lovelock-Nevada.html] {{Pershing County, Nevada}} {{Nevada}} [[Category:Cities in Nevada]] [[Category:Closed facilities of the United States Navy]] [[Category:County seats in Nevada]] [[Category:Cities in Pershing County, Nevada]]

<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]] |postal_code = 89447 |area_code = [[Area code 775|775]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 32-85400 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0848686 |website = {{URL|www.yerington.net}} |footnotes = }} '''Yerington''' ([[Washo language|Washo]]: yéŋtɨn <ref>{{Cite web | title = The Washo Project Online Dictionary | accessdate = 2012-05-27 | url = http://washo.uchicago.edu/dictionary/results.php?SearchBy=GlossIndex&SearchKey=y }}</ref>) is a city in [[Lyon County, Nevada]], United States. The population was 3,048 at the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]].<ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/G001/1600000US3285400| title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Yerington city, Nevada| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=January 25, 2013}}</ref> It is named after [[Henry M. Yerington]]<!-- Henry Marvin Yerington, d. 1910 -->, Superintendent of the [[Virginia and Truckee Railroad]] from 1868 to 1910. It is the county seat of Lyon County.
==Geography== Yerington is located at the intersection of [[U.S. Route 95 Alternate (Schurz–Fernley, Nevada)|US 95A]] and [[Nevada State Route 208]]. According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|22.3|km2|disp=flip}}, all land.<ref name="Census 2010"/> [[File:Watering alfalfa field.JPG|thumb|left|bottom|Watering an alfalfa field in Yerington, Nevada]]
==Demographics== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 2,883 people, 1,203 households, and 729 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 1,698.4 people per square mile (654.8/km²). There were 1,359 housing units at an average density of 800.6 per square mile (308.7/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 84.53% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.17% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 6.24% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.38% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 5.79% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2.88% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 15.44% of the population.
There were 1,203 households out of which 27.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 46.1% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 10.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 39.4% were non-families. 35.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 19.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.29, and the average family size was 2.97.
In the city the population was spread out with 24.7% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 22.2% from 25 to 44, 19.4% from 45 to 64, and 25.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females there were 99.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 92.7 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $31,151, and the median income for a family was $39,038. Males had a median income of $25,724 versus $24,550 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $18,640. About 12.6% of families and 17.9% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 26.2% of those under age 18 and 12.3% of those age 65 or over.
==Politics== The [[Yerington Paiute Tribe of the Yerington Colony and Campbell Ranch]] is headquartered in Yerington.<ref>Conway, Lorna. [http://www.ypt-nsn.gov/ "Tribal Government."] ''Yerington Paiute Tribe].'' 2007 (retrieved 12 December 2008)</ref>
==Notable residents== * [[Nevada Barr]], writer * [[Jesse Brinkley]], professional boxer, contestant on season one of ''[[The Contender (TV series)|The Contender]]''
==Wilson Ranch fire balloon== During [[World War II]], one of many [[Japan]]ese [[fire balloon]]s launched at the United States landed on the Wilson Ranch near Yerington. The ranchers, not knowing what it was, attempted to notify the authorities by mail, but did not receive a response until after they cut it up and used it as a hay tarp. It was one of seven fire balloons turned in to the Army by Nevadans.
==In popular culture==
"[[Darcy Farrow]]," a folk song written by [[Steve Gillette]] and [[Tom Campbell (folksinger)|Tom Campbell]], mentions Yerington ("Her eyes shone bright like the pretty lights / That shine in the night out of Yerington town," 7-8) and other places and landmarks in the area, including [[Virginia City, Nevada|Virginia City]], the Carson Valley, and the [[Truckee River]]. Critics have noted the geographical inaccuracy in the line "The [[Walker River|Walker]] runs down to the Carson Valley plain." The most popular version of "Darcy Farrow" was performed by [[John Denver]] and recorded on his multi-platinum album ''[[Rocky Mountain High (album)|Rocky Mountain High]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gillette|first=Steve|title=Darcy Farrow Lyrics|url=http://compassrosemusic.com/DarcyFarrowLyrics.asp|work=Steve Gillette & Cindy Mangsen website|accessdate = 2013-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Steele-Carlin | first = Sherril | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Darcy Farrow, NV | work = | publisher = American Profile | date = 2001-10-14 | url = http://www.americanprofile.com/spotlights/article/1569.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-14}}</ref>
==Climate== Yerington experiences a [[desert climate]] and has a [[Köppen Climate Classification]] of ''Bwk''.<ref>[http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weather-summary.php3?s=36457&cityname=Yerington%2C+Nevada%2C+United+States+of+America&units= Climate Summary for Yerington, Nevada]</ref> {{Weather box |location = Yerington, Nevada |single line = Yes |metric first = Yes |Jan high F = 46 |Feb high F = 52 |Mar high F = 60 |Apr high F = 68 |May high F = 74 |Jun high F = 83 |Jul high F = 92 |Aug high F = 90 |Sep high F = 82 |Oct high F = 71 |Nov high F = 58 |Dec high F = 48 |Year high F = 69 |Jan low F = 15 |Feb low F = 21 |Mar low F = 25 |Apr low F = 31 |May low F = 38 |Jun low F = 44 |Jul low F = 49 |Aug low F = 47 |Sep low F = 39 |Oct low F = 30 |Nov low F = 21 |Dec low F = 16 |Year low F = 31 |Jan precipitation inch = 0.6 |Feb precipitation inch = 0.6 |Mar precipitation inch = 0.4 |Apr precipitation inch = 0.4 |May precipitation inch = 0.5 |Jun precipitation inch = 0.4 |Jul precipitation inch = 0.2 |Aug precipitation inch = 0.2 |Sep precipitation inch = 0.3 |Oct precipitation inch = 0.3 |Nov precipitation inch = 0.4 |Dec precipitation inch = 0.5 |Year precipitation inch = 4.8 |source 1 = Weatherbase <ref name=Weatherbase> {{cite web |url =http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weather.php3?s=36457&cityname=Yerington-Nevada |publisher=Weatherbase |title=Weatherbase.com |year=2013 }} Retrieved on September 8, 2013. </ref> |date=September 2013 }}

|imagesize = 250px |image_caption = [[John Ascuaga's Nugget Casino Resort|John Ascuaga's Nugget]] in downtown Sparks |image_flag = |image_seal = |pushpin_map = USA Nevada |pushpin_label_position = |pushpin_map_caption = Sparks is located in [[Washoe County, Nevada|Washoe County]], Northern [[Nevada]] |pushpin_mapsize = 176 |image_map = |map_caption = Location in Washoe county |image_map1 = |mapsize1 = |map_caption1 = |coordinates_region = US-NV |subdivision_type = [[List of countries|Country]] |subdivision_name = [[United States]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Political divisions of the United States|State]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Nevada]] |subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in Nevada|County]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Washoe County, Nevada|Washoe]] |government_footnotes = |government_type = [[Council-manager government|Council-manager]] |leader_title = [[Mayor]] |leader_name = [[Geno Martini]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]) |established_title = Founded |established_date = 1905 |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = 93.0 |area_land_km2 = 92.6 |area_water_km2 = 0.4 |population_as_of = 2010 |population_total = 90264 |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[Pacific Standard Time Zone|PST]] |utc_offset = -8 |timezone_DST = [[Pacific Daylight Time|PDT]] |utc_offset_DST = -7 |elevation_ft = 4413 |latd = 39 |latm = 33 |lats = 16 |latNS = N |longd = 119 |longm = 44 |longs = 8 |longEW = W |area_total_sq_mi = |area_land_sq_mi = |area_water_sq_mi = |elevation_m = 1345 |website = {{URL|cityofsparks.us}} |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 89431–89436 |area_code = [[Area code 775|775]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 32-68400 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0856391 |footnotes = {{designation list|embed=yes|designation1=Nevada Historical Marker|designation1_number=88}} }} '''Sparks''' is a [[city]] in [[Washoe County, Nevada|Washoe County]], [[Nevada]], [[United States]]. It was established in 1905 and is located just east of [[Reno, Nevada|Reno]]. The 2010 U.S. Census Bureau population count was 90,264.{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml| title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Sparks city, Nevada| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=January 16, 2013}} It is the fifth most populous city in Nevada. Sparks is often referred to as half of a [[Twin cities (geographical proximity)|twin city]] (i.e., "[[Reno-Sparks]]"). ==History== In the early historical period, the area that is now Sparks was inhabited by the [[Washoe people]]. Euro-American settlement of the area began in the early 1850s, with the early settlers often selling [[cattle]] to [[California]]-bound emigrants. The emigrants' cattle were commonly weak and sick from the long and arduous journey along the [[California Trail]], and they needed fresh animals to take them over the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]. As part of the deal, the settlers would receive the emigrants' cattle, and then fatten them up to sell to the next year's batch of emigrants.{{cn|date = October 2013}} The [[population density]] in the area remained very low until 1904 when the [[Southern Pacific Railroad]] built a [[rail yard|switch yard]] and maintenance sheds there. The city that sprung up around them was first called '''Harriman''' after [[E. H. Harriman]], president of the Southern Pacific. The city was quickly renamed '''Sparks''' after [[John Sparks (Nevada politician)|John Sparks]], the governor of Nevada at that time.{{cn|date = October 2013}} Sparks remained a small and sleepy town until the 1950s, when economic growth in Reno triggered a housing boom north of the railroad in the area of Sparks. During the 1970s, the area south of the railroad started to fill up with warehouses and light industry. In 1984 the tower for [[John Ascuaga's Nugget Casino Resort]] was finished, giving Sparks its first, and currently only, high-rise [[casino]]. In 1996, the redevelopment effort of the old and unsightly B Street business district across from the Nugget that started in the early 1980s took a step forward with the opening of a multi-screen movie complex and the construction of a plaza area. This area, now known as Victorian Square, is a pedestrian-friendly district that hosts many open-air events.{{cn|date = October 2013}} Under direction of the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]], a comprehensive dynamic water quality [[computer model]], the [[DSSAM Model]], was developed (Earth Metrics, 1987) to analyze impacts of a variety of land use and [[stormwater]] management decisions throughout the {{convert|3120|sqmi|adj=on}} [[Truckee River]] basin; this model was used to develop a set of [[surface runoff]] [[stormwater]] management measures for Sparks in the 1980s.{{cn|date = October 2013}} On 21 October 2013, Sparks Middle School in Sparks was the scene of a [[Sparks Middle School shooting|school shooting]]. A 12-year-old student, who was armed with a [[handgun]] opened fire at the school that morning before classes began, killing one mathematics teacher and apparently also himself. Two others were wounded.[http://ca.news.yahoo.com/shooter-opens-fire-nevada-middle-school-154307896.html?vp=1 October 2013 school shooting] ==Geography and climate== According to the U.S. Census Bureau, Sparks has a total area of {{convert|93.0|sqkm|disp=flip}}, of which {{convert|92.6|sqkm|disp=flip}} is land and {{convert|0.4|sqkm|disp=flip}}, or 0.47%, is water. Stormwater surface runoff from the city drains into the [[Truckee River]], a sensitive waterway that empties into [[Pyramid Lake (Nevada)|Pyramid Lake]], which has no outlet and is the habitat of two endangered species. Sparks has a [[semi-arid climate]]. Due to frequent low humidity, especially in the summer, daily temperature ranges are fairly wide. The average January temperatures are a maximum of {{convert|48.3|F|C}} and a minimum of {{convert|23.5|F|C}}. Average July temperatures are a maximum of {{convert|91.7|F|C}} and a minimum of {{convert|53.6|F|C}}. There are an average of 52.3 days with highs of {{convert|90|F|C}} and an average of 141.7 days with lows of {{convert|32|F|C}}. The record high temperature was {{convert|108|F|C}} on July 11, 2002, and the record low temperature was {{convert|-19|F|C}} on February 4, 2001. Average annual precipitation in Sparks is {{convert|7.82|in|mm}}. There are an average of 48 days with measurable precipitation. The wettest year was 1998 with {{convert|15.07|in|mm}} and the driest was 1990 with {{convert|4.65|in|mm}}. The most precipitation in one month was {{convert|3.81|in|mm}} in December 2005, including the most precipitation in 24 hours ({{convert|1.61|in|mm}}) on December 31. Average snowfall per year is {{convert|7.0|in|mm}}. The most snow in one year was {{convert|21.0|in|mm}} in 2008 and the most snow in one month was {{convert|19.6|in|mm}} in February 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrcc.dri.edu/cgi-bin/cliMAIN.pl?nv7697 |title=SPARKS, NEVADA - Climate Summary |publisher=Wrcc.dri.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-01-16}} ===Average monthly temperatures and precipitation===
{{Weather box |imperial first = Y |location = Sparks, Nevada |single line = Y |Jan high F = 47 |Feb high F = 53 |Mar high F = 59 |Apr high F = 65 |May high F = 74 |Jun high F = 84 |Jul high F = 92 |Aug high F = 90 |Sep high F = 83 |Oct high F = 71 |Nov high F = 56 |Dec high F = 47 |Jan low F = 23 |Feb low F = 26 |Mar low F = 31 |Apr low F = 35 |May low F = 42 |Jun low F = 48 |Jul low F = 53 |Aug low F = 51 |Sep low F = 44 |Oct low F = 35 |Nov low F = 28 |Dec low F = 23 |Jan precipitation inch = 1.12 |Feb precipitation inch = 0.97 |Mar precipitation inch = 0.86 |Apr precipitation inch = 0.60 |May precipitation inch = 0.63 |Jun precipitation inch = 0.47 |Jul precipitation inch = 0.28 |Aug precipitation inch = 0.32 |Sep precipitation inch = 0.41 |Oct precipitation inch = 0.63 |Nov precipitation inch = 0.91 |Dec precipitation inch = 1.13 |precipitation colour = green |source 1 = {{cite web |url=http://www.weather.com/weather/wxclimatology/monthly/89431 |title=Monthly Averages for Sparks, NV (89431) |accessdate=October 18, 2012 |publisher=The Weather Channel}} |date=October 2012 }}
==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1900= | 1910=2500 | 1920=3238 | 1930=4508 | 1940=5318 | 1950=8203 | 1960=16618 | 1970=24187 | 1980=40780 | 1990=53667 | 2000=66346 | 2010=90264 | footnote=source:Moffatt, Riley. ''Population History of Western U.S. Cities & Towns, 1850–1990''. [[Lanham, Maryland|Lanham]]: Scarecrow, 1996, 158. |}} As of the [[census]] of 2010, there were 90,264 people, 33,502 households, and 22,598 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was {{convert|3761|PD/sqmi}}. There were 36,455 housing units at an average density of {{convert|1519|PD/sqmi|abbr=on}}. The racial makeup of the city was 74.5% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 2.6% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 1.2% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 5.9% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.6% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 11.2% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4.0% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 26.3% of the population.{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml| title=Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (DP-1): Sparks city, Nevada| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=January 16, 2013}} There were 33,502 households out of which 36.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 47.7% were headed by [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 13.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 32.5% were non-families. Of all households 24.3% were made up of individuals and 8.3% were someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. In the city the population was spread out with 25.8% under the age of 18, 9.7% from 18 to 24, 27.7% from 25 to 44, 25.6% from 45 to 64, and 11.3% who were 65 years of age or older. For every 100 females there were 97.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 94.7 males. In 2011 the estimated median income for a household in the city was $50,568, and the median income for a family was $57,905. About 10.9% of families and 13.4% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 21.2% of those under age 18 and 9.4% of those age 65 or over.{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml| title=Selected Economic Characteristics: 2011 American Community Survey 1-Year Estimates (DP03): Sparks city, Nevada| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=January 16, 2013}} ==Culture== Image:Welcome to Sparks.jpg|Welcome to Sparks File:Old Glendale School, Sparks, Nevada.jpg|The Old Glendale School, built in 1864. Glendale preceded Reno, and is now part of Sparks. [[Nevada Historical Marker]] No. 169. * [[Best in the West Nugget Rib Cook-off]] * [[Great Basin Brewing Company]] * [[John Ascuaga's Nugget Casino Resort]] * [[Outlets at Legends]], shopping destination * [[Rail City Casino]] * [[Sparks Western Village]] ==Education== ===Public schools=== Sparks is located within the [[Washoe County School District]]. The following public schools are located within the city limits:{{cite web|url=http://www.washoe.k12.nv.us/schools/| title=Schools| publisher=Washoe County School District| accessdate=January 16, 2013}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} ;High schools *[[Edward C. Reed High School]] *[[Sparks High School]] ;Middle schools *Dilworth Middle School *Mendive Middle School *[[Sparks Middle School]] {{col-break}} ;Elementary schools *Beasley Elementary School *Diedrichsen Elementary School *Drake Elementary School *Dunn Elementary School *Greenbrae Elementary School *Juniper Elementary School *Lincoln Park Elementary School {{col-break}} *Maxwell Elementary School *Mitchell Elementary School *Moss Elementary School *Risley Elementary School *Sepulveda Elementary School *Kate Smith Elementary School *Van Gorder Elementary School *Whitehead Elementary School {{col-end}} ===Private schools=== Sparks has a few private elementary schools, including [[Legacy Christian School]], [[Excel Christian School]], and the Lamplight Christian School.{{cite web|url=http://www.lcsreno.com/ |title=Lamplight Christian School |publisher=Lcsreno.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-16}} Reno has several private high schools, including [[Bishop Manogue High School]] and [[Sage Ridge School]]. ==Transportation== The [[Union Pacific Railroad]] and [[Interstate 80]] run east-west through the center of Sparks. The Union Pacific has a significant [[rail yard]] south of I-80 near downtown and is a central part of the area's [[industrial park]]. [[Nevada State Route 445|State Route 445 (Pyramid Way)]] and [[Nevada State Route 659|State Route 659 (McCarran Blvd)]] are the city's major north-south thoroughfares. Pyramid Way runs from downtown to [[Pyramid Lake (Nevada)|Pyramid Lake]] and has been designated a [[Nevada Scenic Byway]]. Sparks is also served by the nearby [[Reno–Tahoe International Airport]]. [[Amtrak]], the national passenger rail system, provided service to Sparks until [[Sparks (Amtrak station)|May 2009]]. ==Notable current and former residents== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ '''Notable people from Sparks, Nevada''' |- !Name||Native||Profession||Reason for notability |- |[[T. J. Bell]]|| ||[[Motor sport]] driver||[[Auto Racing Club of America]] |- |[[Scott Cousins]]|| ||Professional baseball player|| Plays for the [[Miami Marlins]] |- |[[Brian Crane]]|| ||Syndicated cartoonist||''[[Pickles (comic strip)|Pickles]]'' |- |[[Jim Gibbons (U.S. politician)|Jim Gibbons]]|| ||Politician||[[List of Governors of Nevada|Former Governor of Nevada]] |- |[[Jena Malone]]|| ||Actress||''[[Donnie Darko]]'', ''[[The Ruins (film)|The Ruins]]'' |- |[[Jake McGee]]|| ||Professional baseball player|| Plays for the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] |- |[[Brian Retterer]]|| ||Swimmer||NCAA Champion at [[Stanford University]] |- |[[Karl Rove]]|| ||Political activist, lobbyist and pundit|| [[White House Deputy Chief of Staff|Deputy White House Chief of Staff]] |- |[[David S. Loeb]]|| ||Businessman|| Co-founder of [[Bank of America Home Loans|Countrywide]] and [[OneWest Bank|IndyMac]] |} == See also == {{Portal|Nevada}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Earth Metrics Inc, C.M. Hogan, Marc Papineau, et al. ''Development of a dynamic water quality simulation model for the Truckee River'', Environmental Protection Agency Technology Series, Washington D.C. (1987) ==External links== * [http://cityofsparks.us/ City of Sparks official website] * [http://www.visitrenotahoe.com/destination/sparks/ Reno-Tahoe CVB Sparks Pages] * [http://thechambernv.org/ Chamber of Commerce] {{Washoe County, Nevada}} {{Nevada}} {{Coord|39|33|16|N|119|44|8|W|type:city|display=title}} [[Category:Cities in Nevada]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1850]] [[Category:Cities in Washoe County, Nevada]] [[Category:Reno–Sparks metropolitan area]] [[Category:Sparks, Nevada| ]] [[Category:1850 establishments in the United States]]

|elevation_m = 1495 |elevation_ft = 4905 |latd = 40 |latm = 42 |lats = 51 |latNS = N |longd = 116 |longm = 6 |longs = 47 |longEW = W |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]] |postal_code = 89822 |area_code = [[Area code 775|775]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 32-08900 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0847272 |website = [http://www.explorecarlinnv.com www.explorecarlinnv.com] |footnotes = {{designation list|embed=yes|designation1=Nevada Historical Marker|designation1_number=112}} }} '''Carlin''' is a city located near the western border of [[Elko County, Nevada|Elko County]] in northeast [[Nevada]], {{convert|23|mi|km}} west of the city of [[Elko, Nevada|Elko]]. It is part of the Elko [[Elko micropolitan area|Micropolitan Statistical Area]]. Carlin sits along [[Interstate 80]] at an elevation of approximately {{convert|4900|ft|m}}. As of the [[United States Census 2000|2000 census]], its population was 2,161. The city was named for Civil War general [[William Passmore Carlin]].[http://www.epodunk.com/cgi-bin/genInfo.php?locIndex=53235 Profile for Carlin NV] Its slogan is "Where The Train Stops...And the Gold Rush Begins".{{cite web | last = City of Carlin | title = City of Carlin official website | url = http://www.explorecarlinnv.com | accessdate = 2007-06-17 }} Carlin was the home of the [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] [[Medicine man]] [[Rolling Thunder (person)|John "Rolling Thunder" Pope]], who had worked as a [[brakeman]] on the railway.{{cite book | last = Boyd | first = Doug | title = Rolling Thunder ISBN 0-385-28859-X | publisher = Delta | year = 1974 | location = New York}} ==Geography== Carlin is located at {{Coord|40|42|51|N|116|6|47|W|type:city}}. To the northwest is the [[Carlin Unconformity|Carlin Trend]], one of the most productive [[Gold mining in the United States|gold mining]] areas in the United States. According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|9.2|sqmi|km2}}, all of it land. ===Climate=== {{Weather box |imperial first = Y |location = Carlin, Nevada |single line = Y |Jan record high F = 65 |Feb record high F = 70 |Mar record high F = 80 |Apr record high F = 85 |May record high F = 98 |Jun record high F = 100 |Jul record high F = 106 |Aug record high F = 101 |Sep record high F = 98 |Oct record high F = 89 |Nov record high F = 76 |Dec record high F = 60 |year record high F= 106 |Jan high F = 39 |Feb high F = 43 |Mar high F = 53 |Apr high F = 59 |May high F = 69 |Jun high F = 80 |Jul high F = 91 |Aug high F = 89 |Sep high F = 78 |Oct high F = 65 |Nov high F = 50 |Dec high F = 39 |year high F= |Jan low F = 11 |Feb low F = 14 |Mar low F = 22 |Apr low F = 25 |May low F = 32 |Jun low F = 37 |Jul low F = 41 |Aug low F = 39 |Sep low F = 32 |Oct low F = 23 |Nov low F = 16 |Dec low F = 10 |year low F= 25 |Jan record low F = −29 |Feb record low F = −32 |Mar record low F = −12 |Apr record low F = 5 |May record low F = 9 |Jun record low F = 19 |Jul record low F = 25 |Aug record low F = 20 |Sep record low F = 8 |Oct record low F = −4 |Nov record low F = −11 |Dec record low F = −40 |year record low F= −40 |Jan precipitation inch = 0.87 |Feb precipitation inch = 0.75 |Mar precipitation inch = 1.04 |Apr precipitation inch = 1.25 |May precipitation inch = 1.30 |Jun precipitation inch = 0.80 |Jul precipitation inch = 0.37 |Aug precipitation inch = 0.44 |Sep precipitation inch = 0.77 |Oct precipitation inch = 0.99 |Nov precipitation inch = 0.99 |Dec precipitation inch = 1.05 |year precipitation inch= 10.62 |source = The Weather Channel {{cite web |url = http://www.weather.com/weather/wxclimatology/monthly/graph/USNV0013 |title = Climate Statistics for Carlin, Nevada |accessdate = February 12, 2012}} }} ==Demographics== [[Image:View of Calin, Nevada from Interstate 80.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Carlin, Nevada.]] As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 2,161 people, 792 households, and 579 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 234.6 people per square mile (90.6/km²). There were 1,014 housing units at an average density of 110.1 per square mile (42.5/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 91.90% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 0.05% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 1.76% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.60% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.05% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 3.79% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 1.85% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 8.38% of the population. There were 792 households out of which 39.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 58.6% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 7.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.8% were non-families. 21.6% of all households were made up of individuals and 5.8% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.73 and the average family size was 3.17. In the city the population was spread out with 30.8% under the age of 18, 7.4% from 18 to 24, 31.1% from 25 to 44, 23.5% from 45 to 64, and 7.3% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females there were 108.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 114.3 males. The median income for a household in the city was $49,571, and the median income for a family was $51,716. Males had a median income of $47,396 versus $21,813 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $19,377. About 4.1% of families and 7.8% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 10.2% of those under age 18 and 3.0% of those age 65 or over. ==History== On August 12, 1939 a train operated under the name ''[[City of San Francisco (train)|City of San Francisco]]'' derailed while crossing a bridge near Carlin, killing 24 and injuring 121. The wreck appeared to have been caused by sabotage but remains unsolved to this day. The train was operated by a joint partnership of the [[Chicago and North Western Railway]], the [[Southern Pacific Railroad]], and the [[Union Pacific Railroad]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Nevada}} * [[Gold mining in Nevada]] * [[Newmont Mining Corporation]] has a large gold-mining operation near Carlin * [[Carlin Tunnel]] ==External links== * [http://www.explorecarlinnv.com/ City of Carlin official website] * [http://www.elkocountynv.net/ Elko County] * [http://www.elkocountylibrary.org/carlinbranch.htm Carlin Branch Library] {{Coord|40.714186|-116.113127|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Elko County, Nevada}} [[Category:Cities in Nevada]] [[Category:Cities in Elko County, Nevada]] [[Category:Elko, Nevada micropolitan area]]

<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 89445–89446 |area_code = [[Area code 775|775]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 32-84800 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0844996 |website = [http://www.winnemuccacity.org/ www.winnemuccacity.org] |footnotes = }} '''Winnemucca''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=EN-US-Winnemucca.ogg|ˌ|w|ɪ|n|ə|ˈ|m|ʌ|k|ə}}) is a city in and the [[county seat]] of [[Humboldt County, Nevada]], United States.{{GR|6|dateform=mdy}} As of the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]], the city had a total population of 7,396,<ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/G001/1600000US3284800| title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Winnemucca city, Nevada| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=January 24, 2013}}</ref> up 3.1 percent from the 2000 census figure of 7,174. [[Interstate 80 in Nevada|Interstate 80]] passes through the city, where it meets [[U.S. Route 95 in Nevada|U.S. Route 95]].
== History and culture == The town received its name from a local Indian chief of the same name, which is loosely translated as "One Moccasin." His daughter Sarah Winnemucca was an advocate for education and fair treatment of the Paiute and Shoshone tribes in the area. On September 16, 1868, the [[Central Pacific Railroad]] reached Winnemucca, and was officially opened on October 1 of that year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marden|first=J. P.|title=The History of Winnemucca|publisher=Central Pacific Railroad Photographic History Museum|year=2005|url=http://cprr.org/Museum/Winnemucca_Marden.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}</ref>
On September 19, 1900, [[Butch Cassidy|Butch Cassidy's]] gang robbed the First National Bank of Winnemucca of $32,640.
Winnemucca is featured prominently in the novel ''Revoltingly Young'' by [[C.D. Payne]], and is also a setting in ''[[More Tales of the City (novel)|More Tales of the City]]'' by [[Armistead Maupin]]. The city is also referenced in the North American version of the (originally Australian) song [[I've Been Everywhere|"I've Been Everywhere."]] The song begins, "I was totin' my pack along the dusty Winnemucca road."
Winnemucca's [[Prostitution in Nevada|brothel district]], while smaller now than in the 1980s, is known as "The Line" or "The Ring Circle" based on the layout of the street where the brothels are located, and sex workers in the town must register their vehicles with the local police.<ref>{{cite web|last=Giang|first=Vivian| title=Everything You Ever Wanted To Know About Prostitution In Nevada|work=Business Insider|date=December 14, 2011|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/prostitution-legal-nevada-prostitutes-brothels-sex-2011-12?op=1|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}</ref>
According to a billboard spotted along [[Nevada State Route 140|State Route 140]] (the "Winnemucca to the Sea Highway"), Winnemucca styles itself "The City of Paved Streets".
Winnemucca is home to the Buckaroo Hall of Fame and Heritage Museum. It is also the headquarters of the Flawedcast Network.
==Chinatown== In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Winnemucca was the location of a vibrant Chinatown. The Chinese originally came to the area working on the transcontinental [[Central Pacific Railroad]], which reached Winnemucca in 1868. Some remained or returned to settle. Around 400 Chinese formed a community in the town during the 1890s. Among the prominent buildings was the Joss House on Baud Street, a place of worship and celebration that was visited by [[Sun Yat-Sen]], later to become Chinese president, in 1911 on a revolutionary fund raising tour of the United States.<ref>Chew, James R. "Boyhood Days in Winnemucca, 1901–1910." ''Nevada Historical Society Quarterly'' 1998 41(3): 206–209. ISSN 0047-9462</ref> The Joss House, the last remains of Chinatown, was demolished on March 8, 1955, by Winnemucca City Council.<ref>{{cite news | title = Humboldt Pioneers effort to save famed Joss House rebuffed by City Council | date = 7 Jan 1955 | url = http://newspaperarchive.com/reno-evening-gazette/1955-01-07/page-8 | work = Reno Evening Gazette | page = 8 | accessdate = June 7, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Stanley | last = Miller | title = Baud Street Winnemucca | date = Sept 1963 | url = http://mydesertmagazine.com/files/196309-DesertMagazine-1963-September.pdf | work = Desert Magazine | page = 23 | accessdate = June 7, 2012}}</ref>
==Geography and climate== Winnemucca is located at {{Coord|40|58|6|N|117|43|36|W|type:city}} (40.968212, −117.726662).{{GR|1|dateform=mdy}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|24.3|km2|disp=flip}}, all land.<ref name="Census 2010"/>
Winnemucca's climate is [[Semi-arid climate|semi-arid]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''[[Semi-arid climate#Cold Semi-arid climates|''BSk'']]''), averaging a mere 8.3 inches (212 mm) of precipitation annually. Summer days tend to be hot, but the temperature drops significantly at night. Winters are cold and somewhat snowy, with 22.7 inches (57.7 cm) falling during a typical year. The highest recorded temperature in Winnemucca was 109 °F (43 °C), on July 11, 2002, and the lowest recorded temperature was −37 °F (−38 °C) on December 22, 1990.<ref name = TWC/> Freezing ==Demographics== [[File:Winnemucca South Bridge Street.jpg|thumb|left|South Bridge Street in downtown Winnemucca]]
{{USCensusPop |1860= |1870=290 |1880=763 |1890=1307 |1900=1110 |1910=1786 |1920=1934 |1930=1989 |1940=2485 |1950=2827 |1960=3453 |1970=3587 |1980=4140 |1990=6134 |2000=7174 |2010=7396 |estref= | footnote=source:<ref>Moffatt, Riley. ''Population History of Western U.S. Cities & Towns, 1850–1990''. [[Lanham, Maryland|Lanham]]: Scarecrow, 1996, 159.</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.census.gov/popest/cities/files/SUB-EST2007-32.csv | title = Subcounty population estimates: Nevada 2000–2007| format = [[comma-separated values|CSV]] | publisher = [[United States Census Bureau]], Population Division | date = March 18, 2009 | accessdate = May 9, 2009 | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090331141911/http://www.census.gov/popest/cities/files/SUB-EST2007-32.csv <!--Added by H3llBot--> | archivedate = March 31, 2009}}</ref> |}}
As of the census{{GR|2|dateform=mdy}} of 2000, there were 7,174 people, 2,736 households, and 1,824 families residing in the city. The population density was 867.5 people per square mile (334.9/km²). There were 3,280 housing units at an average density of 396.6 per square mile (153.1/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 83.41% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 2.23% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 0.89% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.32% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.03% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 9.60% from [[Race (U.S. Census)|other races]], and 3.51% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 20.74% of the population.
There were 2,736 households out of which 37.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 53.9% were married couples living together, 8.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 33.3% were non-families. 27.1% of all households were made up of individuals and 8.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.21.
In the city the population was spread out with 30.2% under the age of 18, 7.9% from 18 to 24, 30.6% from 25 to 44, 22.3% from 45 to 64, and 9.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females there were 105.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 104.5 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $46,699, and the median income for a family was $53,681. Males had a median income of $47,917 versus $26,682 for females. The per capita income for the city was $21,441. About 7.5% of families and 9.5% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.8% of those under the age of 18 and 8.1% of those 65 and older.
==Politics== The [[Winnemucca Indian Colony of Nevada]] has its headquarters in Winnemucca.<ref>[http://www.ncai.org/index.php?ppgst_selectpro189=23&id=119 "Federal Recognized Indian Tribes."] ''National Congress of the American Indian.'' 2009 (Retrieved Dec 9, 2008)</ref>
==Transportation== [[File:Winnemucca state bank and trust large.jpg|thumb|Winnemucca State Bank and Trust building is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Nevada|National Register of Historic Places.]]]] [[File:Sunset winnemucca nevada.jpg|thumb|left|Sunset from the Winnemucca Mountain Road.]] [[File:Winnemucca Basque Festival.jpg|thumb|right|Winnemucca Basque Festival.]] [[Amtrak]], the national passenger rail system, provides service to Winnemucca. The [[California Zephyr]] provides a daily service in both directions between San Francisco and Chicago. The [[Winnemucca (Amtrak station)|Winnemucca passenger rail station]], at 209 West Railroad Street, is unstaffed and on-site ticket sales are not available.
Historically, Winnemucca was a station on the [[Transcontinental Railroad]].
Winnemucca is the half-way point between [[Salt Lake City]] and San Francisco along [[Interstate 80 in Nevada|Interstate 80]], which passes through town. [[U.S. Route 95 in Nevada|US Route 95]] also goes through Winnemucca.
Winnemucca's airport is [[Winnemucca Municipal Airport]]. There are no scheduled passenger services.
==Media== ''The Humboldt Sun'' is the local newspaper.
==Employment== Many of Winnemucca's residents are employed by mining companies such as [[Newmont]] and [[Barrick Gold]] or by companies serving the mining industry. Carry-On Trailer employs over 100 residents at their manufacturing facility in the Airport Industrial Park. Other employers include the many casinos, hotels and restaurants located in the city.
Winnemucca Farms operates the world's largest potato dehydration plant.<ref>{{ cite web |author=Sherril Steele-Carlin|title= Basquing in Winnemucca |url=http://www.americanprofile.com/spotlights/article/1056.html | work=americanprofile.com |date= May 27, 2001 }}</ref>
==Education== [[Humboldt County School District]] operates schools serving Winnemucca.
Three K-4 elementary schools, [[Grass Valley (Pershing County)|Grass Valley]], Sonoma Heights, and Winnemucca Grammar School, serve sections of Winnemucca. All of Winnemucca is zoned to French Ford Middle School (5–6), Winnemucca Junior High School (7–8), and [[Albert M. Lowry High School]] (9–12).

Ashurst]] - United States Senator. *[[Horace F. Bartine]] - Member of the U.S. House of Representatives. *[[Howard P. Becker]] - sociology professor. *[[Bill Berry (basketball)|Bill Berry]] - basketball coach. *[[George S. Nixon]] - United States Senator. *[[Gordon Rhodes]] - baseball player. *[[Bob Tallman]] - rodeo announcer. *[[Clarence D. Van Duzer]] - Member of the U.S. House of Representatives; had his ashes scattered on the Humboldt River near Winnemucca.

<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 89406, 89407, 89496 |area_code = [[Area code 775|775]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 32-24100 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0840412 |website = [http://www.cityoffallon.com www.cityoffallon.com] |footnotes = }} [[Image:FallonNV8104.JPG|thumb|250px|Corn Field in Fallon, Nevada, August 2004.]] '''Fallon''' is a city in [[Churchill County, Nevada|Churchill County]], [[Nevada]], [[United States]], in the western part of the state. The population was 8,600 at time of the [[United States Census, 2010|2010 census]]. Fallon is the [[county seat]] of Churchill County,{{GR|6}} and is located in the [[Lahontan Valley]].
Fallon and Churchill County are mostly agricultural areas. Although the area is arid, approximately {{convert|50,000|acre|km2}} of its pastureland are irrigated with water from the [[Truckee–Carson Irrigation District]]. The principal crop grown is alfalfa for livestock feed. The "Heart O' Gold" cantaloupes of Churchill County were once distributed across the U.S.A., but are now grown mostly for consumption in Nevada.
The largest single employer in Fallon and Churchill County is the important [[Naval Air Station Fallon]], a training [[airfield]] that has been the home of the [[U.S. Navy]]'s Naval Strike and Air Warfare Center including the TOPGUN training program since 1996, when it was moved here from [[Naval Air Station Miramar]] with that Air Station transferred to the [[U.S. Marine Corps]].
[[U.S. Route 50 in Nevada|U.S. Highway 50]] (US 50, east–west) is one of the two [[highway]]s that intersect through the city. The other one is [[U.S. Route 95 in Nevada|US 95]] (north–south), so Fallon is at the crossroads of an important pair of [[U.S. Numbered Highways]]. Fallon is one of the towns on the so-called "Loneliest Highway in America", the stretch of US 50 across most of Nevada that is known for its remoteness. Eastbound travelers from Fallon must drive {{convert|110|mi}} to find the next town, [[Austin, Nevada|Austin]].
==Geography== Fallon is located at the [[geographic coordinates]] {{Coord|39|28|22|N|118|46|44|W|type:city}} (39.472792, -118.778826).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], this city has a total area of {{convert|3.1|sqmi|km2}}, of which {{convert|3.0|sqmi|km2}} is land and {{convert|0.04|sqmi|km2}} (0.65%) is water.
==Climate== Fallon experiences a desert climate, with hot summers and cold winters. Due to Fallon's altitude and aridity, the [[Diurnal temperature variation]] is quite substantial, especially in the summer months. Fallon's climate is quite dry, due to its location in the [[Rain Shadow|rain shadow]] of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]. Summer days can be hot, but temperatures are cooler than in deserts such as the [[Mojave Desert|Mojave]], [[Sonoran Desert|Sonoran]], and [[Chihuahuan Desert]], due to Fallon's altitude and higher [[latitude]] north of the equator. In the winter, daytime temperatures are usually above freezing, but nights can be bitterly cold. Fallon can experience heavy fog in winter, known as [[Ice fog|pogonip]].

==Demographics== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 7,536 people, 3,004 households, and 1,877 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 2,474.1 people per square mile (954.0/km²). There were 3,336 housing units at an average density of 1,095.2 per square mile (422.3/km²). The racial makeup of the city was 76.50% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 2.00% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 3.00% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 4.70% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.3% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 0.3% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 3.3% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 9.9% of the population.
There were 3,004 households out of which 35.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 42.7% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 15.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 37.5% were non-families. 30.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 11.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.45 and the average family size was 3.06.
In the city the population was spread out with 28.4% under the age of 18, 10.3% from 18 to 24, 29.7% from 25 to 44, 19.4% from 45 to 64, and 12.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 32 years. For every 100 females there were 95.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.5 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $35,935, and the median income for a family was $41,433. Males had a median income of $35,356 versus $22,818 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $16,919. About 9.5% of families and 12.6% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 15.6% of those under age 18 and 10.3% of those age 65 or over.
==Politics== The [[Paiute-Shoshone Tribe of the Fallon Reservation and Colony]] is headquartered in Fallon.<ref>[http://500nations.com/Nevada_Tribes.asp "Nevada Tribes."] ''500 Nations.'' 2009 (retrieved 8 December 2009)</ref>
[[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Martin Heinrich]] was born in Fallon.
==Nuclear weapons testing== Los Alamos National Laboratory, in conjunction with the Department of Defense, conducted an underground nuclear test 28 miles southeast of Fallon, at 5 p.m. on October 26, 1963.
Named ''[[Project Shoal]]'', the 12.5 kiloton detonation was part of the [[Vela Uniform]] program. The device exploded at a depth of 1,205 feet below ground surface.<ref name="ndep.nv.gov">{{cite web | title = Remediation Project Shoal Area, Nevada Division of Environmental Protection | url = http://ndep.nv.gov/shoal/SHOAL1.HTM}}</ref> The site is located in Gote Flat in the [[Sand Springs Range]].
Access to the Project Shoal Area is unrestricted.<ref name="ndep.nv.gov"/> Access to the area is by Highway 50, Nevada Highway 839, then to an improved gravel road to the site.
==Grimes Point== [[Image:GrimesPointNV.JPG|thumb|250x|[[Petroglyph]] at Grimes Point]] Seven miles east of Fallon, adjacent to Highway 50, is the Grimes Point Petroglyph Trail.<ref>[http://www.nv.blm.gov/carson/Recreation/Rec_grimes_pt.htm nv.blm.gov]</ref> The Trail features rocks with carvings as much as eight thousand years old, created by native peoples who were drawn to the shores of ancient [[Lake Lahontan]]. The Trail is approximately one-half mile long on a level path. Free brochures explaining the native art are available. There is also a cave where bats dwell. The path begins to rise as it goes from the now level lake bottom to the once higher bank where inhabited with caves.
The Grimes Point site is a part of a much larger archaeological complex, which includes a wide variety of materials, caves, shelters, and other archaeological sites. The site is located on what was once a shoreline of Pleistocene Lake Lahontan and is best known for the cupules, which are small pits dug out of the rock surface and found on hundreds of boulders in the area.
This site was the primary locality used by archaeologists Robert Heizer and Martin Baumhoff to define the “Pit and Groove Style” of rock art, which is thought by many to be the oldest type of rock art found in Nevada. It does share certain characteristics with other Great Basin rock art known to be of great antiquity called Great Basin Carved Abstract. Specifically, the depth of engraving and the width of the engraved lines are much greater than other rock art types that appear to be of more recent manufacture, a characteristic also noted elsewhere.
Archaeologist Karen Nissen included Grimes Point in her analyses of rock art sites in western Nevada and concluded that rock art was generally associated with hunting locales, an idea popular at that time but somewhat less so today.
Grimes had been very badly abused prior to its listing in the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) in 1972, though the Bureau of Land Management began restoration and development for public exploration by the late 1970s and 1980s. The site is located off U.S. 50 east of Fallon and open to the public year-round.<ref name="Grimes Point">{{cite web|last=Woody|first=Alanah|title=Grimes Point|url=http://www.onlinenevada.org/Grimes_Point|publisher=Online Nevada Encyclopedia|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref>
==In popular culture== * According to the ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' episode "A Sew Sew Evening", Al was stationed in Fallon when he served in the Navy, which was a disappointment to him since he wanted to see the world. Interestingly, he used the native pronunciation of "Nevada," which is unusual for an outsider, especially someone in the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]].
* Films such as ''[[Top Gun]]'' and ''[[Kerosene Cowboys]]'' have been shot there and at [[Naval Air Station Fallon]].
* ''[[The Wizard (film)|The Wizard]]'', starring [[Fred Savage]] and [[Beau Bridges]], was shot in and around Fallon as well.
* ''[[The Go-Getter (film)|The Go-Getter]]'', starring [[Zooey Deschanel]] and [[Jena Malone]], mentions Fallon many times and even brings up Fallon's annual Heart 'O Gold Cantaloupe Festival. <!-- Registry designation --> {{designation list|embed=yes|designation1=Nevada Historical Marker|designation1_number=106}}}} {{Coord|40|50|N|115|46|W|type:city|display=title}} '''Elko''' ([[Shoshoni language|Shoshoni]]: '''Natakkoa''', 'Rocks Piled on One Another')<ref>Beverly Crum & Jon P. Dayley, ''Shoshoni Texts'' (1997, Boise State University), pg. 167</ref> is a city in [[Elko County, Nevada|Elko County]], [[Nevada]], [[United States]]. The population was 18,297 at the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]]. It is the [[county seat]] of [[Elko County, Nevada|Elko County]].{{GR|6}}<ref name="Profile for Elko, Nevada, NV">{{cite web|url=http://www.epodunk.com/cgi-bin/genInfo.php?locIndex=17670|title=Profile for Elko, Nevada, NV|publisher=ePodunk|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> The city straddles the [[Humboldt River]].
Elko is the principal city of the [[Elko micropolitan area|Elko Micropolitan Statistical Area]], a [[United States micropolitan area|micropolitan area]] that covers Elko and [[Eureka County, Nevada|Eureka]] counties<ref>[http://www.census.gov/population/www/estimates/metro_general/2006/List5.txt MICROPOLITAN STATISTICAL AREAS AND COMPONENTS]{{dead link|date=September 2013}}, [[Office of Management and Budget]], 2007-05-11. Accessed 2008-07-27.</ref> and had a combined population of 46,942 at the [[2000 United States Census|2000 census]].{{GR|8}} It is the largest city for over {{convert|130|mi|km}} in all directions, making it, as its city motto states, "The Heart of Northeast Nevada".
It is home to [[Great Basin College]], as well as to the [[National Weather Service]] Weather Forecast Office serving most of northern and central Nevada.
==History== Though Elko lies along the route of the historic [[California Trail]], it was first inhabited only in 1868, when it was at the east end of the railroad tracks built by [[Central Pacific Railroad]] (the portion of the [[First transcontinental railroad (North America)|First Transcontinental Railroad]] built from California to Utah). When the railroad crews moved on, Elko remained, serving as a center for ranching, mining, rail freight and general supplies.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite journal|last=Hickson|first=Howard|year=1983|month=Fall|title=Elko, Nevada: 1868-1968|journal=Northeastern Nevada Historical Society Quarterly|volume=83|issue=4}}</ref>
[[File:2012-09-21 01-Downtown Elko.jpg|thumb|left|250px|View southwest along Idaho Street near 6th Street in downtown Elko.]] Elko is said to have been named by [[Charles Crocker]], a superintendent of the [[Central Pacific Railroad]]. He was especially fond of animal names and added the letter "o" to Elk. There is no definitive evidence of this naming history, but it has become the widely accepted version.<ref name="Profile for Elko, Nevada, NV"/><ref name="autogenerated1" />
The first [[Elko County Courthouse]] was built in 1869. Elko was officially incorporated as a city in 1917.
In 1925, the Kelly Act (also known as the Airmail Act of 1925) authorized the [[United States Postal Service|U.S. Post Office]] to contract with private airlines for the feeder routes that fed the main transcontinental route. The first commercial airmail flight in the United States was on the 487 mile Airmail Route #5 from [[Pasco, Washington]] to what would become [[Elko Regional Airport]] on April 6, 1926. The flight was piloted by Leon D. Cuddeback and included a brief stop in [[Boise, Idaho]] to pick up more mail.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hickson|first=Howard|year=1970|month=Fall|title=Dirt Runways: Elko Airport - The Early Years (1919-1926)|journal=Northeastern Nevada Historical Society Quarterly|volume=1|issue=2}}</ref>
The 1910 replacement for the [[Elko County Courthouse|original courthouse]] is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The U.S. Post Office-Elko Main, built in 1933, is also listed.
[[File:View of Elko, Nevada from Twin Peaks in the Adobe Range with Spring Creek and the Ruby Mountins visible in the distance.JPG|thumb|right|View of Elko, Nevada from Twin Peaks in the Adobe Range with Spring Creek and the Ruby Mountins visible in the distance]]
==Geography== According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|14.5|sqmi|km2}}, all land; though the path of the [[Humboldt River]] fills from time to time.
===Climate=== Elko's climate is [[Semi-arid climate|semi-arid]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''[[Cold steppe|''BSk'']]''). January is normally the coldest month of the year, with a daily average temperature of {{convert|25.1|°F|1}}. July is normally the warmest month of the year, with a daily average of {{convert|70.2|°F|1}}. There is an average of 1.8 days with {{convert|100|°F|0}}+ highs, 44 days of {{convert|90|°F|0}}+ highs, 198 days of freezing lows, and 12 nights with sub-{{convert|0|°F|0}} lows; the growing season here is short, as the average window for freezing temperatures is September 10 thru June 9. Annual precipitation averages {{convert|9.89|in|cm}}, falling on an average of 81 days. Annual snowfall averages with {{convert|41.5|in|cm}}. There are normally 130 sunny days each year.<ref>climate-zone</ref> The highest temperature on record is {{convert|107|°F|0}}, most recently on July 4, 1981, and the lowest on record is {{convert|-43|°F|0}} on January 21, 1937. The most rainfall in 24 hours was {{convert|4.13|in|cm}} on August 27, 1970. The most rainfall in one month was {{convert|5.71|in|cm}} in January 1916. The most rainfall in one year was {{convert|18.34|in|cm}} in 1983. The least rainfall in one year was {{convert|4.35|in|cm}} in 1919. The most snowfall in one month was {{convert|69.0|in|cm}} in January 1890. The most snowfall in one calendar year was {{convert|100.8|in|cm}} in 1996.{{clarify|95–96 or 96–97?|date=June 2013}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrcc.dri.edu/cgi-bin/cliMAIN.pl?nv2573|title=ELKO WB AIRPORT, NEVADA - Climate Summary|work=wrcc.dri.edu|accessdate=June 6, 2010}}</ref>
